dataset.title: Temperature and Humidity at Soil Surface on Barro Colorado Island - CLOSED 1

creator.organizationName: University of Oklahoma - Kaspari Ant Lab

para.literalLayout: Patterns of biodiversity, such as the increase toward the tropics and the peaked curve during ecological succession, are fundamental phenomena for ecology. Such patterns have multiple, interacting causes, but temperature emerges as a dominant factor across organisms from microbes to trees and mammals, and across terrestrial, marine, and freshwater environments. However, there is little consensus on the underlying mechanisms, even as global temperatures increase and the need to predict their effects becomes more pressing. The purpose of this project is to generate and test theory for how temperature impacts biodiversity through its effect on biochemical processes and metabolic rate. A combination of standardized surveys in the field and controlled experiments in the field and laboratory measure diversity of three taxa -- trees, invertebrates, and microbes -- and key biogeochemical processes of decomposition in seven forests distributed along a geographic gradient of increasing temperature from cold temperate to warm tropical. This data is from a temperature humidity logger placed near the center of the Barro Colorado site macroplots array as part of a macrosystems biodiversity and latitude project supported by the National Science Foundation under Cooperative Agreement DEB#1065836. This data is associated with the project bento bags, but may be used as measures of the soil surface temperature for the dates represented.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Study area at Barro Colorado Island.

contact.organizationName: University of Oklahoma - Kaspari Ant Lab

para.literalLayout: This data is taken from a temperature humidity logger placed near the center of the Barro Colorado site macroplots array. This data is associated with the project bento bags, but may be used as measures of the soil surface temperature for the dates represented. Data was collected using an EXTECH RHT10 temperature/humidity data logger. The data loggers were placed in a dummy decomposition bags with representative versions of the substrates (cellulose, balsa brick and birch popsicle sticks). The experimental treatments were open, meaning that the exposed side of the decomposition bento bag was made of mesh and closed where both sides were made of cloth (limiting access of invertebrates). The open and closed bags were pairs, so there are four files total, with BCI_OPEN1.txt and BCI_CLOSED1.txt being attached to each other and placed no more than 6 inches apart. BCI_OPEN2.txt and BCI_CLOSED2.txt are the second attached pair, placed about 10m from BCI1_ BAGS. Data logger bags were placed and retried by Jelena Bujan (OU). Data was recovered by Michael D. Weiser (OU) using EXTECH RHT10 data acquisition software version 5.6. Problematic records, which may be due to either simple measurement error or due to not starting or stopping the data logger in the field, have been marked with "#" by Michael D. Weiser (OU). DATA COLLECTED FROM:05-14-2013 11:26:58 TO:06-14-2013 15:26:58. Sample Points:749. Sample Rate:3600 sec.

physical.objectName: Kaspari Lab Temperature Humidity Logger Data (BCI_CLOSED1)

attribute.attributeDefinition: The number of the logged reading, numbered sequentially starting from 1.

textDomain.definition: The number of the logged reading, numbered sequentially starting from 1.

attribute.attributeDefinition: The date of the reading in MM-DD-YYYY format.
The time of the reading in 00:00:00 format.
The ratio of the water vapor density (mass per unit volume) to the saturation water vapor density, expressed in percent.

Dew point temperature is defined as the temperature to which the air would have to cool (at constant pressure and constant water vapor content) in order to reach saturation. Expressed in degrees Celsius.
